TopicTitle: Joining fuel tanks into the hexagon - reusable first stage.

Articles.Content:
I'm trying to build a super-heavy lift rocket with reusable first stage, however I stumbled upon a problem - each time I decouple my bottom stage falls apart. I can't keep all my tanks connected.

Here's the connections structure:


[FONT=courier new]|_____UPPER STAGE_____|
>--D--<         >--D--<
|     |         |     |
|     |-problem-|     |[/FONT]

D = decoupler

problem is with my connection between left and right fuel tank. As you know, strouts vaporise on a decoupled stage, even if no force was applied on them. I can't really connect tanks to each other using girders cause they're spawned in a hexagonal symmetry mode, and the game doesn't allow making connections of that sort by simply going from one part the existing another one. I stumbled upon similar problem some time ago, and the solution was to use Clamp-O-Trons, so there we go:

Now if I go and launch the rocket - clamp-o-trons do connect fine - if I right-click them I do have a "decouple" option just like they should have and everything holds beautifully....

However as soon as I decouple - clamp-o-trons loose connection.

How can I prevent it? Or what can I do to keep my tanks together?

i think a picture of the entire rocket would help here, but you should attach things radially to a central tank using radial decouplers and seprotrons.
Yep, and that's what makes the challenge - rocket doesn't have any central tank.

Try using a single structural thing in the middle, directly below the upper stage, and attach the tanks to it radially.

So instead of:

[FONT=courier new]|_____UPPER STAGE_____|
>--D--<         >--D--<
|     |         |     |
|     |-problem-|     |[/FONT]

Try:

[FONT=courier new]|_____UPPER STAGE_____|
I_____I >--D--< I_____I
|     |    |    |     |
|     |----o----|     |[/FONT]

And where I've put "I"s you can use struts.

Doesn't matter what the structural thing in the middle is, so long as it can take the stresses. Girder, structural element, whatever.

Now, because the idea is to make a reusable rocket - I don't want to have a discardable decouplers (in a setup: First drop the first stage connected through the core, then drop decouplers on the engines to uncover them).

(ps. if only stock game would have build-in interstage fairings with adjustable sizes... )

Yep, and that's what makes the challenge - rocket doesn't have any central tank.

This confuses me. If you have more fuel you Generally have more dV, with a center tank your center engine can burn longer, getting you higher into the atmosphere with fewer stages. I understand that you don't want to use mods, but it might be best to to get the functionality you want while still maintaining some degree of efficiency.

From the picture you linked I see you've got something in the middle that you can put a decoupler on. Just put a decoupler on that (looks like the bottom of a Kerbodyne tank) and then use that central decoupler on a central structure. It's a quick and easy fix.

I don't think you can solve it any other way. If you want six decouplers on top, you will get six independent subassemblies below that. If you want to keep your lower stage together, you have to attach it as one piece.

Though I suspect that the docking ports actually should work, only you have such large forces that they're torn apart. You may try attaching clamp-o-trons directly to the tanks in such a fashion that they point towards each other, the docking connections forming a ring that spans all six tanks. Probably better to have several such docking rings at different heights.

If you insist on not having a central structural element the only way to assemble it is to start with one tank and work your way around attaching the other tanks radially to each other without using symmetry, like so:


        O       O        OO      OO        OO
O  ->  O  ->   O     -> O    -> O     ->  O  O
                O        O       OO        OO

Strutting the boosters together. Unfortunately, this will mean that only one of the decouplers put at the top of the stacks will have a proper connection if the ship above is to remain intact; otherwise it will split into separate pieces like your booster is doing now. Much simpler to use a central structural element to connect the two stages as others have suggested, but if you really want a completely hollow stage that stays together after staging the above method will work.

An upper stage:

The circularization stage has just separated, a moment ago it was strutted into a single unit. Since circularization is complete, I could deorbit those boosters individually but couldn't keep all four as one unit because they were attached to the stacks above.

Problem is that a single central column probably can transmit the forces. Or rather, you can't transmit your forces to the column in the first place. I only place KR-2Ls below some weight, as they've torn every radial connection I came up with.

But.... haha!, Heureka: Put large docking ports on top of your first stage; also place such docking ports under the decouplers. Ports should connect when ship loads (may need a few stability enhancers); Thus you get both, a six-point connection and decouplers.
